current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To clarify that the anti-kickback laws apply to qualified health plans, the federally-facilitated marketplaces, and other plans and  programs under title I of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, and for other purposes.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the private health insurance issuers that offer Medicare Advantage plans under the Medicare program both receive  Federal dollars directly from the Federal Government, with the issuers of qualified health plans receiving Federal dollars through tax credit subsidies and the issuers of Medicare Advantage plans receiving payments from the Medicare Trust Funds.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act

text.#text: The private health insurance issuers who offer qualified health plans through marketplaces  established under the

The Federal Government facilitates applications for and enrollment in qualified health plans through the federally-facilitated marketplaces and State exchanges in a similar manner to the way the Federal Government facilitates applications for and enrollment in plans under the Medicare Advantage program and the Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program through federally funded call centers, web portals, and consumer assistance personnel.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and other prohibited acts involving Federal health care programs are subject to civil and criminal penalties under the

False Claims Act

text.#text: separately estimate  with respect to each of the following, the impact of excluding qualified health plans, federally-facilitated marketplaces and State Exchanges,  and any other plan or program established or funded under
Health care premiums (with and without non-federally funded subsidies).

The use of brand name versus generic drugs.
